questions.question: According to the sources, plagiarism is defined as:
questions.option_a: Using the work of others with proper citation.
questions.option_b: Using the work of others without acknowledgment of the source [1].
questions.option_d: Expressing someone else's ideas in your own words with citation.
questions.explanation: Plagiarism is the use of the work of others without acknowledgment of your source of information or inspiration [1].

questions.question: Which of the following constitutes plagiarism according to the sources?
questions.option_a: Providing a reference list at the end of your work [2].
questions.option_c: Paraphrasing without stating where the information comes from [3].
questions.option_d: Writing all your notes in your own words [3].
questions.explanation: Paraphrasing what you read or hear without stating where it comes from is considered plagiarism [3].

questions.question: To avoid plagiarism when paraphrasing, you should:
questions.option_a: Change only a few words while keeping the original sentence structure.
questions.option_b: Write in your own words while giving credit to the original author [3].
questions.option_c: Copy and paste the original text and then add citations.
questions.explanation: To avoid plagiarism through paraphrasing, you should write in your own words while giving credit to the original author [3].

questions.question: Referencing in academic work involves the appropriate acknowledgment of:
questions.option_a: Only direct quotations from other sources.
questions.option_b: Ideas and work that originate from another person [2].
questions.explanation: Referencing is the appropriate acknowledgment of ideas and work that originate from another person [2].

questions.question: One of the reasons why referencing is important is that it:
questions.option_b: Indicates what material is your original work [4].
questions.option_c: Restricts the reader from accessing external material.
questions.option_d: Always indicates that the material is from a popular online website.
questions.explanation: Referencing indicates what material is your original work since you have provided a citation for work that is not your own [4].

questions.question: The two main elements used in referencing are:
questions.option_c: A citation in the text and an entry in a reference list [5].
questions.explanation: The two elements used in referencing are a citation in the text of the assignment (in-text citation) and an entry in a reference list at the end [5].

questions.question: In the IEEE citation style, in-text references are:
questions.option_a: Given with author names and year of publication.
questions.option_b: Numbered in the order of appearance in the article [6].
questions.option_c: Listed alphabetically by author's last name.
questions.option_d: Placed as footnotes at the bottom of each page.
questions.explanation: In the IEEE citation style, in-text references are numbered [1] in the order of appearance in the article [6].

questions.question: The reference list in the IEEE style is:
questions.option_b: Ordered as they appear in the in-text references [6].
questions.option_d: Not required if in-text citations are used.
questions.explanation: The reference list in the IEEE style is displayed at the end of the article and the references are ordered as they appear in the in-text references (in order of citation) [6].

questions.question: Paraphrasing is defined as:
questions.option_a: Shortening a text to its main points.
questions.option_b: Expressing a statement or text in different words, while maintaining the original meaning [7].
questions.option_c: Copying a text verbatim and citing it.
questions.option_d: Providing a critical analysis of a text.
questions.explanation: Paraphrasing is expressing a statement or text in different words, while maintaining the original meaning [7].

questions.question: One important reason to paraphrase is to:
questions.option_a: Increase the word count of your assignment.
questions.explanation: We need to paraphrase to avoid plagiarism [7].

questions.question: Which of the following is a paraphrasing technique mentioned in the sources?
questions.option_a: Using the same word order as the original text.
questions.explanation: Using synonyms appropriately is a paraphrasing technique [8].

questions.question: Summarizing involves:
questions.option_a: Expanding on the original text with additional details.
questions.option_b: Expressing the main ideas of a text in your own words [9].
questions.option_c: Translating the text into another language.
questions.explanation: Summarizing involves identifying main ideas and using your own words [9].

questions.question: When summarizing, it is important to:
questions.option_a: Include every detail from the original text.
questions.option_d: Keep the same sentence structure as the original.
questions.explanation: When summarizing, you should remove unnecessary details [9].

questions.question: To maintain coherence in a summary, you can:
questions.option_c: Repeat the same words and phrases.
questions.explanation: You can use conjunctions for coherence when summarizing [10].

questions.question: When describing a process, understanding the process involves considering whether it is:
questions.explanation: Understanding the process involves considering if it is a man-made or a natural process [11].

questions.question: When describing a process using a diagram, you should first:
questions.explanation: When describing a process using a diagram, you should first introduce the diagram [12].

questions.question: In describing each stage of a process, you should:
questions.option_a: Only focus on the materials added.
questions.explanation: In detailing each stage of the process, you should say what each stage does [13].

questions.question: When describing a process, the sources suggest using:
questions.option_b: Simple present and simple present passive voice [13].
questions.explanation: When describing a process, use simple present and simple present passive [13].

questions.question: Features of academic writing style include:
questions.explanation: Features of academic writing include precision [14].

questions.question: In academic writing, you should generally avoid:
questions.explanation: In academic writing, avoid colloquial words and expressions [14].

questions.question: To achieve objectivity in academic writing, you can:
questions.option_b: Include your personal opinions and biases.
questions.explanation: To achieve objectivity, use passive voice [16].

questions.question: An example of a phrase to avoid in formal academic writing is:
questions.explanation: 'Sort of' is a colloquial expression to avoid in academic writing [14].

questions.question: When using acronyms in academic writing, you should:
questions.option_a: Only use them if the audience is familiar with them.
questions.option_b: Write the name in full the first time with the acronym in brackets [15].
questions.explanation: Write the name in full the first time with the acronym in brackets immediately after [15].

questions.question: The passive voice is formed by using:
questions.option_a: The base form of the verb.
questions.option_b: The verb 'to be' followed by the past participle [17].
questions.option_c: The present participle of the verb.
questions.option_d: The verb 'to have' followed by the past participle.
questions.explanation: We form the passive by using the verb to be followed by the past participle [17].

questions.question: The passive voice is often used when:
questions.option_a: The subject performing the action is the main focus.
questions.option_b: Who or what causes the action is unknown or unimportant [18].
questions.option_d: In narrative writing to emphasize the actor.
questions.explanation: We use the passive voice when who or what causes the action is unknown or unimportant [18].

questions.question: In the sentence 'The room is cleaned by the students,' the voice is:
questions.explanation: The sentence 'The room is cleaned by the students' is in the passive voice [18].

questions.question: To change the active sentence 'Somebody cleans these rooms everyday' to passive, it becomes:
questions.option_a: Somebody is cleaning these rooms everyday.
questions.option_c: These rooms are cleaned everyday by somebody [17].
questions.explanation: The passive form of 'Somebody cleans these rooms everyday' is 'These rooms are cleaned everyday by somebody' [17].

questions.question: Transitive verbs are action verbs that:
questions.option_a: Do not require an object to complete their meaning [19].
questions.option_b: Require an object to complete their meaning [19].
questions.option_c: Cannot be used in the passive voice.
questions.option_d: Are always followed by a preposition.
questions.explanation: Transitive verbs are action verbs that require an object to complete their meaning. Without an object the sentence will not be clear [19].

questions.question: Intransitive verbs are action verbs that:
questions.option_a: Require an object to complete their meaning [19].
questions.option_b: Do not require an object to complete their meaning [19].
questions.option_c: Are always used in the passive voice.
questions.option_d: Must be followed by an adverb.
questions.explanation: Intransitive verbs are action verbs that do not require an object to complete their meaning [19].

questions.question: Which of the following verbs cannot be used in the passive voice according to the sources?
questions.explanation: Following verbs cannot be used in Passive: Occur, resemble, rise, look like, happen, equal, arise, agree with, fall, exist, mean, consist (of), contain, depend (on), hold, result (from), become, lack, suit, fit, comprise [21, 22].

questions.question: Academic vocabulary is the vocabulary used in:
questions.explanation: Academic vocabulary is the vocabulary which can be used in academic contexts such as writing assignments [23].

questions.question: A feature to avoid in academic vocabulary is:
questions.explanation: Avoid contractions in academic vocabulary [24].

questions.question: 'Dude' is an example of:
questions.explanation: 'Dude' is a slang word from casual conversation [24].

questions.question: Instead of 'set up' (a phrasal verb), a more academic alternative could be:
questions.explanation: A more formal vocabulary for 'set up' could be 'established' [25].

questions.question: Instead of 'gone up' in 'Cost of living has gone up,' a more academic alternative is:
questions.explanation: A more formal vocabulary for 'gone up' is 'increased' [26].

questions.question: Critical reading is described as a more ______ way of reading.
questions.explanation: Critical reading is a more ACTIVE way of reading [27].

questions.question: Critical reading involves:
questions.option_a: Simply accepting what the text says.
questions.option_b: Memorizing all the facts in the text.
questions.option_c: Analyzing, interpreting, and sometimes evaluating the text [27].
questions.explanation: Critical reading is a process of analyzing, interpreting and, sometimes, evaluating [27].

questions.question: Skimming is a reading technique used to:
questions.option_b: Get a detailed understanding of every word.
questions.option_c: Get a general idea of what the text is about [28].
questions.option_d: Analyze the author's writing style in depth.
questions.explanation: The main purpose of skimming is to get a general idea/sense of what the text is about [28].

questions.question: When skimming, you typically read:
questions.option_c: The title, introduction, first sentences of paragraphs, and conclusion [28, 29].
questions.explanation: How to Skim: Read the title, introduction, first sentence of each paragraph, headings, and the summary or last paragraph [28, 29].

questions.question: Scanning is a reading method used to:
questions.option_a: Understand the overall theme of a text.
questions.option_c: Find a specific piece of information [29].
questions.explanation: Scanning is a quick reading to find a specific piece of information [29].

questions.question: Context clues are:
questions.option_a: Hints found outside the text to understand its meaning.
questions.option_b: Hints found within a sentence, paragraph, or passage to understand unfamiliar words [30].
questions.option_c: The dictionary definition of a word.
questions.explanation: Context clues are hints found within a sentence, paragraph, or passage [30].

questions.question: Examples, synonyms, and antonyms are types of:
questions.explanation: Examples, Synonyms, and Antonyms are types of Context Clues [31].

questions.question: Making inferences while reading involves:
questions.option_a: Directly stating information from the text.
questions.option_b: Finding information explicitly written in the text.
questions.option_c: Drawing conclusions based on evidence and reasoning [32].
questions.explanation: An inference is an idea or conclusion that’s drawn from evidence and reasoning [32].

questions.question: The SQ3R method of critical reading involves which steps in order?
questions.explanation: The SQ3R method involves Skim, Question, Read, Remember (Test your memory), and Review [33].

questions.question: A paragraph is defined as:
questions.option_a: A single sentence that conveys a main idea.
questions.option_b: A group of related sentences that develops one central idea [34].
questions.option_c: A long section of text with multiple ideas.
questions.option_d: A collection of loosely connected sentences.
questions.explanation: A paragraph is a group of sentences that develops and supports one central/main idea [34].

questions.question: The most important sentence in a paragraph is usually the:
questions.explanation: The most important sentence in a paragraph is the topic sentence [35].

questions.question: A topic sentence has two main parts:
questions.option_c: A topic and a controlling idea [35].
questions.explanation: A topic sentence has two parts: a topic and a controlling idea [35].

questions.question: Supporting sentences in a paragraph:
questions.option_b: Explain or prove the idea in the topic sentence [36].
questions.option_c: Summarize the main point of the paragraph.
questions.option_d: Connect one paragraph to the next.
questions.explanation: Supporting sentences explain or prove the idea in the topic sentence [36].

questions.question: A concluding sentence:
questions.option_a: Introduces the main idea of the next paragraph.
questions.option_c: Closes the paragraph and summarizes the main points [37].
questions.option_d: Must always be a direct restatement of the topic sentence.
questions.explanation: A concluding sentence closes the paragraph so that the reader is not left expecting more and often summarizes the main points [37].

questions.question: Transitional signals are used to:
questions.option_b: Connect ideas smoothly within and between paragraphs [34].
questions.option_c: State the main topic of the paragraph.
questions.explanation: Transitional signals help in recognizing the usage of transitions in writing passages [34].

questions.question: 'For example' is a transitional signal used to:
questions.explanation: 'For example' is used to introduce an example [38].

questions.question: 'However' is a transitional signal used to:
questions.explanation: 'However' is used to introduce an opposite idea [38].

questions.question: Logical order in paragraph writing depends on:
questions.explanation: Logical order depends on your topic and your purpose [39].

questions.question: Chronological order in a paragraph is used to present:
questions.option_b: A sequence of events or steps in a process [39].
questions.option_d: Arguments for and against a topic.
questions.explanation: Order by time or chronological order presents a sequence of events or steps in a process [39].

questions.question: In a technical presentation, the primary goal should be to:
questions.option_a: Impress the audience with technical jargon.
questions.option_b: Convey your message to the audience [40].
questions.option_d: Present as much information as possible.
questions.explanation: The primary goal of a technical presentation is what you wish to convey to the audience [40].

questions.question: Analyzing your audience for a technical presentation helps you to:
questions.option_d: Prepare for a completely silent and unresponsive audience.
questions.explanation: Analyze your audience to understand them [41].

questions.question: Each slide in a technical presentation should ideally convey:
questions.explanation: Keep your message streamlined—make a single point per slide [43].

questions.question: Strong titles for slides in a technical presentation should:
questions.option_a: Be vague and open to interpretation.
questions.option_b: Identify where you are on your roadmap [44].
questions.option_c: Contain as much detail as possible.
questions.explanation: The slide title should identify where you are on your roadmap [44].

questions.question: When using visuals in a technical presentation, it is important to:
questions.option_a: Include as much detail as possible in figures.
questions.option_b: Use slides primarily for large amounts of text.
questions.option_c: Simplify figures to convey a clear message [45].
questions.option_d: Avoid introducing your data to the audience.
questions.explanation: The purpose of a figure is to convey a message visually. If you show too much detail, your audience will get distracted [45].

questions.question: Basic rules for slide design in technical presentations include:
questions.option_b: Avoiding the use of key words and phrases.
questions.explanation: Basic rules for slide design include writing in point form and avoiding paragraphs [46].

questions.question: Wordiness in technical presentations should be avoided because it:
questions.option_a: Helps to make slides look more professional.
questions.option_b: Increases the audience's engagement with the speaker.
questions.option_c: Reduces your control over the audience's attention [45].
questions.option_d: Allows for more detailed explanations on each slide.
questions.explanation: The more words on the slide, the less control you have over your audience’s attention [45].

questions.question: When presenting data in a technical presentation, you should:
questions.option_a: Assume the audience already understands it completely.
questions.option_b: Show the data immediately without introduction.
questions.option_c: Make sure your audience will be able to understand your data before you show it [47].
questions.option_d: Use highly complex and unexplained visuals.
questions.explanation: Make sure your audience will be able to understand your data before you show it [47].

questions.question: An assumption made by the speaker in the knitting passage is that:
questions.option_a: All community center instructors are narrow-minded.
questions.option_b: A craft's value can be judged by the instructor's personality [48].
questions.option_c: Knitting is a difficult craft to learn.
questions.explanation: The assumption made by the speaker is that a craft can be judged based on the personality of the instructor [48].

questions.question: The speaker's reasoning about knitting is an example of:
questions.explanation: The speaker's reasoning is an example of over-generalizing from one specific case (their experience with one instructor) [49].

questions.question: The governor's statement about his bill implies that voting against it means:
questions.option_b: You don't care about the quality of children's education [49].
questions.option_c: You have a better educational reform plan.
questions.option_d: You are against any form of change.
questions.explanation: The governor's statement implies that voting against the bill can only mean that you don't care about the quality of the education received by your children [49].

questions.question: The television commercial saying 'Buy a Krups—the superior coffee maker' primarily wants the listener to be impressed with the word:
questions.explanation: The writer of the commercial wants the listener to be impressed with the word 'superior' [50].

questions.question: In the dialogue between the father and son, the son's question about 'several' aims to:
questions.option_a: Argue for going to the ski lodge.
questions.option_c: Make his father be more specific [51].
questions.explanation: In this dialogue the son is trying to make his father be more specific about the number 'several' [51].

questions.question: The argument 'Supporters of the Kinley Bill are college students, farmers, and small businessmen. Vote for the bright future—yes on Kinley' involves the fallacy of:
questions.explanation: The argument involves the fallacy of being loaded with emotional words ['bright future'] [51].

questions.question: Based on the supporters mentioned (college students, farmers, small businessmen), the purpose of the Kinley Bill would most likely be:
questions.option_c: Providing government assistance to hard-working Americans [52].
questions.option_d: Lowering interest rates on loans (though this is less directly implied).
questions.explanation: Providing government assistance to hard-working Americans is the most likely purpose that would appeal to college students, farmers, and small businessmen [52].

questions.question: The passage about Papa's soda shop implies reasons for:
questions.option_a: The high prices at the soda shop.
questions.option_c: The popularity of the soda shop [53].
questions.explanation: The passage implies reasons for the popularity of the soda shop due to Papa's personality and tolerance [53].

questions.question: In the passage about Papa, the writer primarily:
questions.option_a: Compares the soda shop to other places in town.
questions.option_c: Contrasts the personality of Papa and the principal [53].
questions.explanation: The writer contrasts the personality of the two men, Papa and the principal [53].

questions.question: The writer's observations about Papa are apparently based on:
questions.explanation: The writer's observations seem to be based on first hand experience, being someone who knew Papa and the town [54].

questions.question: If Papa and the principal found a hundred dollar bill, the most logical outcome based on their described personalities would be:
questions.option_b: Papa would let the principal keep it (due to Papa's generosity) [54].
questions.option_d: The principal would share it grudgingly.
questions.explanation: Given Papa's generous and kind nature, it is most logical that he would let the stricter principal keep the money [54].
